cards.title: Crying / loud upset
cards.say: I hear you. I am here.
cards.do: Get low, soften your voice, and hold one clear boundary.
cards.ifEscalates: Use fewer words, stay close, and focus on safety.

cards.title: Hitting / biting
cards.say: I am here. I will help keep everyone safe.
cards.do: Move breakable items aside and give arm's-length space.
cards.ifEscalates: Give more space, use fewer words, and repeat one calm line.

cards.title: Public tantrum
cards.say: You are safe. We can take a reset break.
cards.do: Move to a quieter nearby spot.
cards.ifEscalates: Leave this task for now and focus on calming first.

cards.title: Refusing to move
cards.say: You can feel upset. The boundary stays the same.
cards.do: Offer one small choice within the limit.
cards.ifEscalates: Repeat the limit once, then stay nearby and quiet.

cards.title: Running off / unsafe
cards.say: Stop. I will help keep your body safe.
cards.do: Block exits and guide to a safer spot.
cards.ifEscalates: Keep your body between danger and child, then call a support person if needed.

cards.title: I feel overwhelmed
cards.say: I need thirty seconds to steady myself.
cards.do: Place child in a safe spot, take ten slow breaths, then return.
cards.ifEscalates: Pause the plan and lower expectations for this moment.

cards.title: Transition overwhelm
cards.say: Transition time. I will help your body shift.
cards.do: Give one short cue, then guide the first step.
cards.ifEscalates: Return briefly to calm, then retry one small step.

cards.title: Big anger, no words yet
cards.say: Your body is full of big feelings.
cards.do: Stay close and name the feeling once: 'You're really angry.'
cards.ifEscalates: Stay quiet and present. Wait for the wave to pass.

cards.title: Sibling conflict
cards.say: I won't let anyone get hurt. I'm here.
cards.do: Separate calmly, then hear each child briefly.
cards.ifEscalates: Focus on safety only. Sort the rest later.

cards.title: Screen / device off
cards.say: Screen time is over. I'll help you shift.
cards.do: One clear warning, then follow through. Offer a small next step.
cards.ifEscalates: Hold the limit. Stay nearby without re-explaining.

cards.title: Morning rush meltdown
cards.say: We have to go. I'll help you get there.
cards.do: One choice: 'Red shirt or blue?' Then move.

cards.title: Testing the limit
cards.say: The answer is no. I'm right here.
cards.do: State the limit once. Then wait with them.
cards.ifEscalates: Repeat the same line once. Don't negotiate.

cards.title: Sensory overload
cards.say: It's loud (or bright) in here. We can find a quieter spot.
cards.do: Reduce input: dim, quiet, or move to calmer space.

cards.title: Disappointment / didn't get it
cards.say: You wanted that so much. It's hard when we can't have it.
cards.do: Name the feeling. Sit with them. No fix required.
cards.ifEscalates: Stay present. 'I'm here. This feeling will pass.'

cards.title: Too tired meltdown
cards.say: Your body is tired. I'll help you wind down.
cards.do: Lower demands. Offer rest or quiet activity.

lessons.title: Why co-regulation works
lessons.body: During a meltdown, the emotional system is online before executive control can catch up. Co-regulation—staying calm and present—helps the child's nervous system learn what safety feels like. You are not rewarding the tantrum; you are teaching regulation.

lessons.title: Safety first, words second
lessons.body: When there is hitting, throwing, or bolting, your first job is physical safety. Move breakables, block exits, give space. Use one short line. Save the conversation for when everyone is calm.

lessons.title: Public tantrums
lessons.body: Many children release big feelings in the safest relationship—often at home after holding it together elsewhere. In public, move to a quieter spot if you can. One calm line. Ignore judgment; focus on the child.

lessons.title: Holding boundaries with warmth
lessons.body: You can acknowledge feelings and still hold the limit. 'You can feel upset. The boundary stays the same.' One clear line, then wait. Consistency over weeks matters more than any single moment.

lessons.title: When you're overwhelmed
lessons.body: It's okay to take a brief pause. Place the child in a safe spot, take ten slow breaths, then return. Your regulation supports theirs. You can't pour from an empty cup.

lessons.title: Making transitions easier
lessons.body: Transitions are hard for developing brains. Give one short cue, then guide the first step. Offer a small choice when you can. When things escalate, return to calm before retrying.
